headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

componenttext: Welcome to the SunTrust Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this point. Now I'll turn the call over to Ankur Vyas, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you. You may now begin.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to SunTrust's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Thank you for joining us. In addition to today's press release, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press r
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to SunTrust's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Thank you for joining us. In addition to today's press release, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press release, presentation and detailed financial schedules can be accessed at investors.suntrust.com. With me today among other members of our executive management team are: Bill Rogers, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Aleem Gillani, our Chief Financial Officer. Before we get started, I need to might you that our comments today may include forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially. We list the factors that might cause actual results to differ materially in our SEC filings, which are available on our website. 
During the call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures when talking about the company's performance. You can find the reconciliation of these measures to GAAP financial measures in our press release and on our website, investors.suntrust.com. Finally, SunTrust this is not responsible for and does not edit nor guarantee the accuracy of our earnings teleconference transcripts provided by third-parties. The only authorized live and archived webcasts are located on our website. With that, I'll now turn the call over to Bill.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ankur, and good morning, everybody. I'll begin with a brief overview of the quarter and then turn it over to Aleem for additional details, including our results at the business segment level. I'll conclude with a review of our performance in 2015
componenttext:
Thanks, Ankur, and good morning, everybody. I'll begin with a brief overview of the quarter and then turn it over to Aleem for additional details, including our results at the business segment level. I'll conclude with a review of our performance in 2015 as a whole in addition to providing some forward-looking perspectives.
We delivered solid results this quarter, which is a direct result of the focus we've maintained on executing our primary strategies of optimizing our business mix and balance sheet, investing in growth opportunities, improving efficiency and increasing capital return to shareholders. 
For the fourth quarter, we recorded $0.91 of earnings per share, which included $0.03 of discrete tax benefits. When adjusting for noncore items, earnings per share were stable compared with prior quarter and the prior year. Continued improvement in net interest income this quarter was offset by a decline in noninterest income as a result of challenging market conditions in addition to normal quarterly variability. Capital markets related to income was in line with the prior quarter as the slowdown in fixed income markets was offset by higher equity origination fees and trading income, the latter, which was a result of increased client-driven interest rate hedging activities. 
Overall, we're successfully deepening client relationships within our Wholesale Banking platform and benefiting from our diverse business mix and breadth of capabilities. We achieved our goal of attaining a sub-63% efficiency ratio and ended the year with an adjusted tangible efficiency ratio of 62.7%, 24 basis points better than 2014. 
Looking ahead, we remain focused on achieving our long-term goal of the being sub-60% while we continue to diligently manage expenses while also investing in a strategic revenue-generating initiatives throughout the company. We continue to see the benefits of our active balance sheet management and optimization efforts, which drove a 4 basis point improvement in our net interest margin and a $34 million increase in net interest income. This is further realization of a positive shift in our overall earning asset and funding mix.
Average loans were up 2% compared to the third quarter, driven by growth across most sectors, including commercial, consumer direct and residential markets. While loan growth will ebb and flow quarter-to-quarter, we remain confident in our ability to generate growth in segments where returns are appropriate and we can have deeper relationships. However, we are closely manage areas that don't meet those thresholds. 
Average deposits were also up 2%, which is further evidence of the success we're having in deepening client relationships across the company. Growing deposits remains an important part of our strategic efforts to strengthen client relationships and improve profitability, the latter of which is evidenced by the 35% reduction in long-term debts over the past year. The overall asset quality remains favorable. However, we did see an increase in nonperforming loans as a result of deterioration in our energy-related exposure, which Aleem will provide details on later. Provision expense was a less impacted as we've been building reserves in the previous quarters. The net charge-off ratio was 24 basis points, a strong result but likely unsustainable long term. Lastly, our capital position continues to be strong with our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio estimated to be 9.8% on a Basel III fully phased-in basis.
So with that as a brief overview I'll turn it over to Aleem to provide some more details on the quarters performance.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us this morning. Before I jump into the details, I'd like to call your attention to a new table we're presenting on Slide 4, which highlights key metrics over the past 5 quarters and will help y
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us this morning. Before I jump into the details, I'd like to call your attention to a new table we're presenting on Slide 4, which highlights key metrics over the past 5 quarters and will help you analyze our financial performance in an efficient manner. As it is year end, we've added this slide to the main presentation and going forward, you'll find this in the appendix. 
Moving to Slide 5, you can see the net interest margin improved by 4 basis points, driven by higher security deals as a result of slower prepayment speeds, further low-cost deposit growth and lower long-term debt, as we received a full quarter benefit of the $1.7 billion debt reduction in the third quarter. Net interest income increased $34 million sequentially, driven by solid 2% loan and deposit growth and the 4 basis points improvement in NIM. As a result of our activity balance sheet management efforts, overall net interest income has been higher since the first quarter, which we had anticipated would be the trough. For the full year, net interest income declined at 2% entirely due to a decline in commercial loan swap income as a result of lower fixed rates. In 2016, commercial loan swap income will decline modestly relative to 2015, largely due to anticipated increase in LIBOR, which would be more than offset by higher net interest income from the core asset sensitivity of the balance sheet.
Looking ahead, we expect first quarter net interest margin to improve further 3 to 5 basis points relative to the fourth quarter. From there, NIM will likely be relatively stable for the remainder of 2016, assuming we only get one additional increase in the federal bonds rate.
We have been and we'll continue to carefully manage the generation of our overall balance sheet in light of the current low interest rate environment while also insurance our balance sheet is structured to benefit from potential increases in short-term rates. 
Moving on to Slide 6. Adjusted noninterest income declined $32 million sequentially, primarily driven by asset disposition gains in the third quarter and lower Wealth Management-related revenue in the fourth quarter, partially offset by an increase in markets related income.
Wealth Management-related revenue declined to $13 million sequentially, partially due to seasonal trust fees typically earned in the third quarter, but also should to market conditions, which reduced assets under management and client activity. Investment banking income declined $11 million as fixed income originations were negatively impacted by challenging market conditions. Equity originations and M&A, however, remained relatively strong, which is a reflection of the strategic capabilities that we have expanded over the past few years.
Trading income increased $11 million, driven by higher derivative marketing revenue as commercial clients increased their utilization of interest rate swaps to hedge potential changes in rates. Mortgage servicing income improved by $16 million due to higher servicing fees, some of which is seasonal, lower decay expense and better hedge performance. Mortgage production income declined $5 million as lower production was generally offset by improved channel mix.
Service charges on deposits continue to steadily decline, a reflection of the increased transparency and the technology we are providing our clients so they can manage their accounts more effectively. This decline will continue in 2016 in part of driven by enhancements to our hosting ordering process, which once fully implemented will help our clients save more money and reduce our service charges by approximately $10 million per quarter. This transition will occur in the second half of 2016. Compared to the fourth quarter of last year, noninterest income was down 4%, driven by declines across most categories, largely due to the challenging market conditions experienced in the second half of 2015. 
Moving on to expenses on Slide 7. Adjusted noninterest expense increased $35 million sequentially, almost entirely due to $32 million of discrete recoveries recognized in the previous quarter related to the successful resolution of the print reviews mortgage matters. Outside processing and software costs were up $22 million due to higher utilization of certain third-party services in addition to normal quarterly variability. Amortization expense increased by $8 million, similar to last year's increase, as we invested additional capital in low income communities, which was generally offset by a correspondingly lower provision taxes. 
Offsetting these increases was a $35 million declined and personnel costs, driven primarily by lower accruals, uncertain incentive and medical costs as we calibrated expenses to actual performance. While quarterly incentive and benefits cost can be variable, for the full year, incentive compensation increased due to improved business performance in 2015, which is consistent with our pay-for-performance philosophy. 
Compared to the first quarter of last year, adjusted noninterest expense increased 2%, driven by a combination of higher personnel expense and outside processing and software costs. For the full year, adjusted expenses were down 1% compared to 2014 and have declined each of the past 4 years. In fact, adjusted expenses are down 15% since 2011, evidence of our efforts to operate more efficiently. Separately, while not a noninterest expense point, I will highlight that the discrete tax benefits we recognized in 2015 resulted in an effective tax rate of 28% for the full year, which is below what we would consider a more normal range in the low 30s. 
As we look to the first quarter of this year, we anticipate personnel expenses to increase by approximately $100 million due to the typical seasonal increase in 401(k) and FICA expenses and also a return to more normal accrual rates on incentive and benefit costs. In addition, our marketing and customer development costs will weigh more heavily in the first half of the year versus the second half as we're introducing a new campaign to further advance our purposes the company. 
Bigger picture, after 4 consecutive years of declines, we expect 2016 expenses to be higher than 2015 as we expect revenues to improve. We will maintain our focus on the efficiency ratio and if revenues do not materialize, we will have to adjust our explain expense base accordingly. As you can see on Slide 8, the adjusted tangible efficiency ratio was 62.2% in the fourth quarter, up slightly over the prior quarter and year. Our full year adjusted tangible efficiency ratio was 62.7%, better than our 2015 target and 24 basis points better than 2014.
For 2016, we're targeting revenue growth that exceeds expense growth and thus, tangible efficiency ratio that improves. That being said, the pace of improvement will be significantly lower than the previous years as our core expenses have already declined substantially and the operating environment, while improving in certain areas, remains challenging overall. Nonetheless, we remain firmly committed to our long-term targets of sub-60%, and achieving this important objective will be a key driver of a delivering additional value to our shareholders. 
Turning to Slide 9. Overall asset quality remains solid during the quarter, evidence by a 24 basis points net charge-off ratio and a 49 basis points NPL ratio. We did experience a deterioration in our energy portfolio, which when combined with the proactive NPL sales in prior quarters, resulted in an NPL ratio that was 14 basis points higher sequentially but was very much in line with last year. As it relates to energy, not much has changed with regard to our exposure and mix. The energy portfolio is 2.2% of the total loan portfolio, which is down 11% over the past year. The exploration and production and oilfield services portfolios, which are the most negatively impacted by prolonged low oil prices, represent a little under 40% of the total energy portfolio or slightly under 1% of total loans. Our reserves for the energy portfolio are approximately 4.5% and when isolated to the two most severely impacted sectors, are near 12%. In addition, total reserves of $1.8 billion have been designated to cover inherent losses in our total loan portfolio. Losses in the E&P and oil field services portfolios will be elevated over the next couple of years and will thus costs overall C&I loss rates to rise from their low levels today. However, given all of the factors I mentioned, we believe our energy-related risks remains very manageable in the context of the overall company. 
The provision for credit losses increased $19 million sequentially and the ALLL ratio declined 5 basis points to 1.29%, consistent with overall credit quality trends. Looking ahead, we expect nonperforming loans and net charge-offs to increase, primarily as a result of further stress in the energy portfolio. Despite this, we would still expect the company's overall net charge-off with to be less than 40 basis points in 2016. Provision expense this year will more closely match net charge-offs as the multiyear improvement in asset quality abates.
Ultimately, our results will be determined by a rigorous quarterly review process, which is informed by trends in all of our loan portfolios, combined with a view on economic conditions. 
Let's turn to the balance sheet trends. Average performing loans were up 2% sequentially, driven by continued momentum in our commercial and consumer portfolios in addition to lower levels of payoffs. Commercial loan growth was broad based and driven by corporate, commercial auto dealer and commercial real estate clients, while consumer loan growth was driven by growth in direct, indirect and guaranteed student loans. The momentum in the consumer direct portfolio continues to be strong, driven by LightStream's, our partnership with GreenSky and further success with our credit card offering. 
On a year-over-year basis, average performing loans grew $2 billion or 2%, driven by 3% growth in C&I and 13% growth in consumer direct and was partially offset by declines in home equity, payoffs and commercial real estate and reductions in indirect consumer loans given our focus on returns. 
In total, we have proactively sold or securitized approximately $5 billion of loans since the middle of 2014. Going forward, we will periodically sell or securitize lower return loans as part of our balance sheet optimization focus, though likely not at the pace of the past 18 months. 
Turning to deposits on Slide 11. Average client deposits were up $2.9 billion or 2% compared to the prior quarter and 8% compared to the prior year, driven by growth across most lines of business. We're pleased with the momentum on the deposit front. Our success here reflects our overall strategic focus on meeting more clients' deposit and payment needs, supplemented by investments in technology platforms and client-facing bankers across both the consumer and private wealth and wholesale sectors. In particular, our corporate liquidity product specialists within Wholesale Banking, continue to do an outstanding job of deepening client relationships with our treasury and payments product offerings. And as Bill referenced earlier, our strong deposit growth directly enabled us to reduce higher cost long-term debt by $4.5 billion or 35% in just the past year. Importantly, the strong growth we have delivered has not resulted in any adverse changes in rates paid or mix. Low-cost deposit growth continues to be strong, while higher-cost deposits have been gradually declining. As interest rates rise, some of these trends will reverse. However, we will maintain a disciplined approach to pricing with a focus on maximizing the value proposition outside of rate paid for our clients.
Slide 12 provides an update on our capital position, which continues to be strong. Our estimated Basel III Common Equity Tier 1 ratio on a fully phased-in basis was up 9.8%. Tangible book value per share was stable sequentially and up 6% compared to the prior year, driven by growth in retained earnings, partially offset by lower AOCIs as a result of higher interest rates. 
For our 2015 capital plan, we repurchased $175 million of common stock and paid a $0.24 dividend in the fourth quarter. In addition, we repurchased an incremental $39 million of common stock in December, which reflects our overall commitment to increase capital return to shareholders. We expect to repurchase approximately $350 million of additional common stock in the first half of 2016 to complete our 2015 capital plan. As a result of our capital return program, we're continuing to drive down share count. Average fully diluted shares outstanding were down 1% sequentially and 3% year-over-year. Lastly, as of January 1, the liquidity coverage ratio is now a formal requirement. We have started the year in full compliance and we'll, of course, maintain that status over the course of 2016. 
Moving to the segment overviews. We'll begin with Consumer Banking and Private Wealth Management on Slide 13.  Net income declined 6% sequentially as elevated market volatility resulted in lower Wealth Management-related revenue. We also had a modest increase in expenses, driven in part by investments in our card offerings as well as various onetime items. Net interest income was up 2% sequentially and 4% annually, benefiting from continued low costs deposit growth and our balance sheet optimization efforts. The strong growth in our consumer direct portfolios has afforded us the opportunity to sell securitized or reduce production in lower return area. Deposits were up 1% sequentially and the 6% for the full year, with much of this growth coming from the deeper relationships with our mass affluent client base, aided by our investments in Premier Bankers and the SummitView platform. 
On a full year basis, CPWM posted strong net income growth of 8%, which is once again the result of strong deposit growth, our balance sheet optimization efforts and further improvements and credit quality. Loan balances declined 3% in 2015 as we sold or securitized approximately $2 billion of loans. But organic consumer nonproduction was solid and increased 5%. 
Noninterest income declined 1% for the full year, largely due to the headwinds wealth management faced in 2015 but also due to the continued decline in service charges. While current market conditions have made growing Wealth Management revenue more challenging, meeting more of our clients' wealth and investment needs continues to be a strategic priority for the company. 
Expenses in CPWM has been well controlled as we have been using efficiency gains to invest in client-facing talent and technology. We continue to generate solid returns from our digital investments and expect this to increase as mobile adoption rates and digital sales trend upwards. Bigger picture, the progress we've made in optimizing balance sheet, meeting more client needs and investing in technology has helped offset the negative impact of the prolonged low rate environment. We're optimistic about the long-term trajectory of this business, both as it executes against its strategic priorities and as the value of our strong deposit franchise is more fully realized in a normal interest rate environment.
Moving to Wholesale Banking on Slide 14. We had a solid quarter in spite of the challenging market conditions. Revenues were down 3% sequentially but stable relative to the prior year. Much of the decline in revenue was driven by overall market volatility, which not only impacted debt origination activity but also resulted in adverse mark-to-market impacts.
Partially mitigating these impacts was strength in other product areas, such as equity originations, equity sales and trading and derivatives marketing, a reflection of the increasing diversity of our business model. Net interest income was up 1% sequentially as a result of strong strong loan and deposit growth, partially offset by margin compression. Overall, net income declined 9% sequentially as a result of declines in noninterest income and increased provision expense. While we have been building reserves for our energy exposure since the fourth quarter of 2014, the prolonged low oil price environment will continue to place pressure on the provision expense in this business. 
On a full year basis, we saw strong performance with a record year for wholesale bank, demonstrated by the 9% increase in net income, driven by broad-based revenue growth, partially offset by energy-related reserve increases. Net interest income was up 6%, driven by 8% loan growth and 16% deposit growth. The loan growth was broad-based across each line of business and most industry verticals, partially offset by intentional reductions in lower-return areas. The deposit momentum within this business also continues to be strong, evidence of the success our liquidity specialists within wholesale are having an the enhancements we've made to our treasury and payment product offerings. 
Noninterest income was up 10% in part due to the 14% growth in investment banking income where we had record years in equity originations, M&A, syndicated and leveraged finance and investment-grade bond originations. The breadth of growth here is reflective of the investments we've made to expand our capabilities and thus, become more of a strategic adviser to all of our wholesale clients. 
The tangible efficiency ratio improved further to 48.6% as we drove further operating leverage while also investing in revenue-generating initiatives. 
In conclusion, while market conditions can be choppy quarter-to-quarter, we're encouraged by our differentiated the business model within Wholesale Banking and are confident in the opportunities we have to expand our client base, meet more of their complex corporate finance and advisory needs and continue to grow our business.
Moving to the mortgage segment. Revenues were stable sequentially as higher servicing income helped to offset the decline in production income. Net income declined $38 million as a result of the $50 million in after-tax discrete benefits recognized in the third quarter. 
On a year-over-year basis, revenue declined by $22 million as a result of lower margins, both in production and our held-for-investment loan portfolio. These declines were partially offset by an increase in servicing income as a result of portfolio acquisitions over the past couple of years. For the full year, we saw $137 million increase in adjusted net income, which is primarily due to the significantly improved credit quality of the loan portfolio, both as a result of the improving housing market and our proactive actions to derisk the book. This improvement was partially offset by a decline in net interest income as a result of $2.3 billion of loan sales in 2014 and lower loan spreads in 2015.
Production volume increased by 38% in 2015 due primarily to higher refinancing activity. New purchase volume also improved in 2015, a broader sign of the continued improvement of the economies in our markets. We also grew the servicing portfolio by 5% as a result of portfolio acquisitions. In both production and servicing, we achieved our objectives of smart, targeted market share growth. I would also like to point out that we successfully switched to a new loan origination system in the second half of 2015, which facilitates a faster and simpler loan process for our clients and teammates but also allowed us to more efficiently meet the new requirements, which became effective October 1. This was a significant and important undertaking, and we have already been able to use our success as a competitive advantage to attract new talent in several of our markets. 
Overall, the mortgage business continues to benefit from improving asset quality and good expense discipline, both of which have allowed this business to become a more steady contributor to the bottom line performance of this company. And with that, I'll turn it back over to Bill to share some concluding perspectives on our performance in 2015 and our outlook for 2016.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Aleem. So coming into last year, we have several key objectives: Continue to improve efficiency, further optimize the balance sheet in order to enhance returns, invest in growth opportunities and increase capital returns.Overall, I'm plea
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Aleem. So coming into last year, we have several key objectives: Continue to improve efficiency, further optimize the balance sheet in order to enhance returns, invest in growth opportunities and increase capital returns.
Overall, I'm pleased with our performance in 2015 as we met each of these objectives. We grew earnings per share by a solid 11%, we met our efficiency ratio goal, we increased ROI by 5 basis points and advanced the revenue growth trajectory of many businesses, all in the context of managing the headwinds associated with the prolonged low interest rate environment.
We also grew tangible book value per share by 6% and returned over 60% of our earnings back to our shareholders, continuing our path of improving capital returns. Our performance is a reflection of the diversity of our business model, where each segment made strong contributions to enhance the financial performance of our company. Within consumer and private wealth, organic production growth and higher return portfolios and continued momentum on the deposit front has allowed us to further optimize the balance sheet. Our investments in digital have allowed us to better identify and meet more client needs while also extracting efficiencies from certain areas. In wholesale, our differentiated business model allowed us to absorb the impact of the more challenging market conditions in the second half of the year and drive strong high single-digit growth in revenue and net income. In particular, I'm pleased with the more integrated One Team approach we delivered to our clients, and that's evidence by a 36% increase in capital markets revenue from the commercial real estate and private wealth businesses.
This increase in client and product diversity will be an important contributor to the long-term growth of Wholesale Banking. And within mortgage, we benefit from the abatement of legacy mortgage-related costs but also from the targeted growth initiatives we have in place to grow production in servicing. The transition to a new origination platform was time-consuming and challenging, but I believe we have the right risk and operational foundation in place to further advance over what gets business. 
So as we look into 2016, we'll remain focused on the same primary strategies of optimizing our business mix and balance sheet, investing in growth opportunities and improving efficiency, all with the goal of creating further value for our clients and shareholders. While the revenue environment is expected to improve, we expect critical to normalize in the nonrecurring benefits we had in 2015 will abate. Subsequently, we'll need to deliver positive operating leverage in 2016 in order to achieve our financial objectives and make further progress towards our long-term target of a sub-60% efficiency ratio. So to conclude, I'd like to take a moment to recognize and thank all of our teammates for their key roles in delivering our 2015 financial results, many of them are on the phone today. Our team is diligently focused on fulfilling our purpose of widening the way to financial well-being for our clients, communities and shareholders. As we look into 2016, we'll further advance this purpose, facilitating a dialogue about money in order to help Americans moved from financial stress to control and ultimately, to confidence. Our team is absolutely ready to go. Now with that, I'll turn it back over to Ankur and we'll begin the Q&A portion.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor of Deutsche Bank.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us some thoughts on your framework in terms of when all is said and done, how do you think the energy book plays out in terms of either default rates or total NPL levels, what the loss content might be and any framework o
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us some thoughts on your framework in terms of when all is said and done, how do you think the energy book plays out in terms of either default rates or total NPL levels, what the loss content might be and any framework on that kind of would be helpful?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take a crack at that. I think when you think about our energy book overall, it's helpful to think about the context. So you know our energy exposure overall is only 2.2% of our total loan book, first of all. Secondly, within that E&P and oil
componenttext: Well, let me take a crack at that. I think when you think about our energy book overall, it's helpful to think about the context. So you know our energy exposure overall is only 2.2% of our total loan book, first of all. Secondly, within that E&P and oil field services are 40%, so only about 1% of our total loan portfolio is in those two sectors which should probably be the sectors most negatively impacted by lower oil prices. Within that, now you think about, we've got about 4.5% of reserves against the entire energy book. So for those two segments, the reserve levels are closer to 12%. So that starts to feel pretty good. And then thoroughly, of course, we've got a total of $1.8 billion of ALLL in total, which is available to cover all of our loans. So as I think about what might happen here in 2016, '17, '18, we will see some increase in NPLs. We will see some increase in provisioning against our energy portfolio. But in the context of the rest of the book, where our resi mortgage exposure continues to get better and better and as charge-off levels and required reserves continue to come down, I think that our 2016 charge-off levels and provision levels for energy actually are looking very manageable.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, just on the loss content. Once the loan is moved to nonperformer, can you remind us, do you take a charge-off on that? And then what's potentially the eventual loss content? Obviously, not all nonperformers are the same, but it takes a while for
componenttext: And then, just on the loss content. Once the loan is moved to nonperformer, can you remind us, do you take a charge-off on that? And then what's potentially the eventual loss content? Obviously, not all nonperformers are the same, but it takes a while for that to be clear, I think, from the outside.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It does. I mean, it will take a while to see how all of this plays out. We build -- we're building up our reserves for energy clients, up client-by-client. You actually made a great point in not all nonperformers have the same loss content. You saw the in
componenttext: It does. I mean, it will take a while to see how all of this plays out. We build -- we're building up our reserves for energy clients, up client-by-client. You actually made a great point in not all nonperformers have the same loss content. You saw the increase in nonperforming loans that we had this quarter. I got to let you know that the vast majority of those nonperforming loans are actually performing. They're still performing today. What we're trying to do here is be prudent and get ahead of the curve on nonperforming loans the same way you saw us do in Q4 '14 when we tried to get ahead of the curve and start to provision early for energy. We're trying to do the same thing here in nonperforming loans.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John McDonald of the Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John McDonald of the Bernstein.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on credit again, the outlook for net charge-offs less than 40 basis points is a bit away from the 24 basis points you did this quarter, recognizing that's a very low charge-off rate of that you are at today. Are you expecting it to kind
componenttext: Just following up on credit again, the outlook for net charge-offs less than 40 basis points is a bit away from the 24 basis points you did this quarter, recognizing that's a very low charge-off rate of that you are at today. Are you expecting it to kind of march up steadily? And is the driver of your outlook for higher charge-offs really just energy? Or do you guys have some other normalization going on?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's mostly just energy as sort of where I think the inflection is, John. We -- we've been saying now for several years that our charge-off levels are unsustainably low. Well, it looks like energy might be the catalyst to actually turn that around. So
componenttext: No, it's mostly just energy as sort of where I think the inflection is, John. We -- we've been saying now for several years that our charge-off levels are unsustainably low. Well, it looks like energy might be the catalyst to actually turn that around. So I do expect that we'll see more provisioning coming in the wholesale book in 2016. But I also expect that the rise in provisioning will be mitigated by the releases that I expect to get out of our consumer and mortgage books as a result of resi mortgage improving.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

componenttext: Yes, and outside of energy, that increase is more a macro combat. I mean to your question, we don't see any particular portfolio segment, geography whatever, you might want to categorize it that we see a particular problem, and it's kind of a macro kind of nonenergy compound.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You could still have some reserve release in the beginning part of the year. It sounds like the gap is going to close between provision and charge-offs but you could still have a little bit of a gap?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Betsy Graseck of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Betsy Graseck of Morgan Stanley.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions, just one more on the energy reserve and one on loan growth. On the energy reserve, you indicative the 4.5%, and the 12%. Could give us a sense as to how you think about oil price when you're making that reserve? Is that on a forward basis,
componenttext: Two questions, just one more on the energy reserve and one on loan growth. On the energy reserve, you indicative the 4.5%, and the 12%. Could give us a sense as to how you think about oil price when you're making that reserve? Is that on a forward basis, on a spot basis? And can you give us some sensitivities to, if oil goes down another $5 or another $10, what happens to the reserve there?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the reserve is built as of December 31, Betsy. So at the time, we used the oil price on that day, which was $37. That's the way the reserve was built. If oil stays down under $30 for a while, yes, we will expect that we will continue to see addition
componenttext: Well, the reserve is built as of December 31, Betsy. So at the time, we used the oil price on that day, which was $37. That's the way the reserve was built. If oil stays down under $30 for a while, yes, we will expect that we will continue to see additional provisioning required. But as I said earlier, I think, we'll be able to mitigate some of that with the benefits we get out of the mortgage book overall. Our price index as you know, are pretty consistent across the industry. And we'll be rebuilding our new price deck for the spring redetermination period very soon.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, no sense of just what kind of order of magnitude change we should expect? Or like should I just take whatever reserve is that you have done today, then have another half? Or given an expectation for if oil stays at $30?
componenttext: Okay, no sense of just what kind of order of magnitude change we should expect? Or like should I just take whatever reserve is that you have done today, then have another half? Or given an expectation for if oil stays at $30?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have a great sense of that for you yet. But it'll be well into eight figures, maybe even get into nine figures in total provisioning over a multiyear period, which in the context of the total PPNR for the company and releases will be coming out of
componenttext: I don't have a great sense of that for you yet. But it'll be well into eight figures, maybe even get into nine figures in total provisioning over a multiyear period, which in the context of the total PPNR for the company and releases will be coming out of market, I think they are very manageable.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to follow up on loan growth and C&I, had a nice inflection this quarter, maybe you can speak to the drivers that was just that less asset sales or more originations, context would be great?
componenttext: Okay. And just to follow up on loan growth and C&I, had a nice inflection this quarter, maybe you can speak to the drivers that was just that less asset sales or more originations, context would be great?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's interesting because we sort of talked about loan growth of being an outcome versus something that we're managing. And if I look at production over the last few quarters, it's actually been very consistent and at a consistent high level. In the f
componenttext: Yes, it's interesting because we sort of talked about loan growth of being an outcome versus something that we're managing. And if I look at production over the last few quarters, it's actually been very consistent and at a consistent high level. In the fourth quarter, in particular, we benefit a little more from some lower paydowns, so paydowns were a little less in the fourth quarter than the third quarter. We had a slight increase in utilization rates. I don't want to mark anything there, but there was a slight increase in utilization rates. So it really is, -- it's a refraction of all the things we have been doing within the case of the fourth quarter, just a little less headwind than we've had in the previous quarters.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin of Jefferies.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to level set on the starting points for the expense side. I got your point about the step-up the annuals, the quarterly step-up and then the marketing in the first half and taking your points about driving to operating leverage. It seems like
componenttext: I just want to level set on the starting points for the expense side. I got your point about the step-up the annuals, the quarterly step-up and then the marketing in the first half and taking your points about driving to operating leverage. It seems like we had great end of the year and we have that normal step-up. So I know we ask this question a lot, but pennies us help us frame kind of the starting point and then I presume we kind of still have that ramp down throughout the year. Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that would be a nice way to think about it. But of course, depends on the revenue environment. If the revenue environment improves in '16 relative to '15, as we are currently anticipating, I think that'll be the driver of expenses increasing '16 rel
componenttext: Well, that would be a nice way to think about it. But of course, depends on the revenue environment. If the revenue environment improves in '16 relative to '15, as we are currently anticipating, I think that'll be the driver of expenses increasing '16 relative to '15. If I try to think about, Ken, an average number and of course, it's going -- this is going to be volatile quarter-to-quarter. But if I try to think about an average number for the year, I'd probably be thinking about something that would be closer to something like $1.35 billion on average, some quarters higher, some quarters lower. And improving slightly, improving efficiency ratio us that revenue appears. If the revenue environment does not improve, then we will have to adjust expenses accordingly. And in that case, I'll just starting thinking a number lower than that, maybe closer to the $1.3 billion.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Understood. And then just a follow-up on that is you guys great job over the past couple of years rightsizing drinking et cetera. How much visibility would you have in that tougher environment? We don't want anticipate happening, but like is there a
componenttext: Yes. Understood. And then just a follow-up on that is you guys great job over the past couple of years rightsizing drinking et cetera. How much visibility would you have in that tougher environment? We don't want anticipate happening, but like is there a lot of opportunity set still inside, if that were to be the case?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is, I think, that's the opportunity still exists because we're still on the path to sub-60. So we have plans underway for expense management and virtually every category. So it's not like, they're not on the shelf already. Our ability to execut
componenttext: Well, this is, I think, that's the opportunity still exists because we're still on the path to sub-60. So we have plans underway for expense management and virtually every category. So it's not like, they're not on the shelf already. Our ability to execute against them would really mean, we'll take a little more Chris, speeding them up in terms of the term, so we have those plans in mind.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, you may have seen the press announcement we had in the last few days about a changes in our real estate footprint. And Riley and in Richmond, we're moving to a new space. We'll take a total number of locations in of those two cities from 11 to five b
componenttext: Ken, you may have seen the press announcement we had in the last few days about a changes in our real estate footprint. And Riley and in Richmond, we're moving to a new space. We'll take a total number of locations in of those two cities from 11 to five between '16 and '17. We'll reduce our square footage and of those areas by 50%, and we'll create a better environment for our teammates just as a sort of a point of info, we've been -- we said, we've been working on branch count and office space reduction over the last several years. We've actually taken out 2.5 million square feet over the last 4 years out of our physical footprint. And we continue to be on that path. Between now and 2018, we'll stay on that becoming more efficient with our use of space.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to answer your question, I mean, we think we have the flexibility on the expense versus revenue achieved in the efficiency ratio target long term. It doesn't exactly work perfectly quarter-to-quarter. I mean, that's the point that I want to make. But w
componenttext: So to answer your question, I mean, we think we have the flexibility on the expense versus revenue achieved in the efficiency ratio target long term. It doesn't exactly work perfectly quarter-to-quarter. I mean, that's the point that I want to make. But we can look ahead and adjust the levers accordingly.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ryan Nash with Goldman Sachs.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I could just follow up on Ken's question. If we were to have expense is coming in $1.35 billion, you implied something like mid-single-digit growth. And Aleem, give me your comments around positive operating leverage. That implies revenue growth sho
componenttext: Maybe I could just follow up on Ken's question. If we were to have expense is coming in $1.35 billion, you implied something like mid-single-digit growth. And Aleem, give me your comments around positive operating leverage. That implies revenue growth should be north of somewhere of 5%. I was just wondering, may be can you talk through the components of revenue growth? How should we think about NII growth? What does it mean for the net interest margin over the last couple of quarters? And on the fee side, how do we think about the split between wholesale and consumer fees? Clearly, consumer will likely be under pressure as you make some changes. Markets have come down, so maybe that will hurt the wealth business, but just trying to contextualize how to think about the different moving pieces on revenue growth?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan, for the question. So if you think about NII overall, for the last several years, it's been essentially flat's, maybe even coming down a small amount. And that's been the effect of declining NIMs essentially being offset by production and gro
componenttext: Thanks, Ryan, for the question. So if you think about NII overall, for the last several years, it's been essentially flat's, maybe even coming down a small amount. And that's been the effect of declining NIMs essentially being offset by production and growth. Now that NIMs are no longer declining, and we're looking for NIM to be essentially stable for 2016, that underlying underlines organic loan production and growth on both assets and liabilities is going to start to show through. And as that shows through, I think we'll see NII start to climb in '16. Sort of as it started to do in '15 after the first quarter. So I think that'll be where you see the growth in revenue. On the fee income side, you're right. We're not really expecting growth in consumer service charges. That's not going to be a growth area for us, but the growth that we've seen overall in wholesale will continue, I think, we'll will continue to appear. The One Team approach that we've got, our ability to meet more of our clients' needs across more products and be a bigger, more of a strategic adviser to our clients, I think, continues to show up. So I think that'll be helpful. And I think mortgage will also become a more sort of consistent contributor to the bottom line. So that's where revenue will appear.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Maybe if I could just follow up on one other question. Given where your reserve is on energy and E&P and oil field services book at 12% and which I think is well above a lot of your peers. I guess, how should we think about the comment that you ma
componenttext: Got it. Maybe if I could just follow up on one other question. Given where your reserve is on energy and E&P and oil field services book at 12% and which I think is well above a lot of your peers. I guess, how should we think about the comment that you made that we should expect continued reserve built from here? And more specifically, if oil prices stayed at these levels, what would be a realistic loss content over a 2-year period? I heard what you said to Betsy, but I'm just trying to understand like why would losses in your book be at that type of level relative to peers you were talking about levels that are half of what you're commenting on?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you know us, we're inherently a conservative company and we try to think conservatively. So I don't know where peers are or what they've got in their book. We are trying to be careful and make sure that we stay ahead of this overall. I think our res
componenttext: Well, you know us, we're inherently a conservative company and we try to think conservatively. So I don't know where peers are or what they've got in their book. We are trying to be careful and make sure that we stay ahead of this overall. I think our reserve levels are very prudent for where we are right now with oil of the station the cycle. But remember, we said these reserves work oil was at $37. And if oil moves into the 20s, we'll have to take account of that and I -- would think that the further oil moves down, the loss content starts to become asymmetric for the industry.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo of CLSA.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, can't wait for the Super Bowl to see your ad.
componenttext: Well, can't wait for the Super Bowl to see your ad.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great.
componenttext: Great.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it comes in the context of 4 years of expense declines and now expense is going higher as you just discussed. So it's the same question I asked last year and you guide your target. But if we don't get rate increases, do you think you can still grow re
componenttext: But it comes in the context of 4 years of expense declines and now expense is going higher as you just discussed. So it's the same question I asked last year and you guide your target. But if we don't get rate increases, do you think you can still grow revenues faster than expenses? And you gave some specific examples about those locations. But if you could say, what are the few main reasons why you think you can improve efficiency if that is the case with rate hikes?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think, Mike, as we went into last year, we were a very clear about saying we were going to improve efficiency irrespective of rates. So we sort of take that off the table. Now it looks like we're only projecting two rate hikes and wanted to end
componenttext: Yes. And I think, Mike, as we went into last year, we were a very clear about saying we were going to improve efficiency irrespective of rates. So we sort of take that off the table. Now it looks like we're only projecting two rate hikes and wanted to end the year. So I think were still taking a pretty conservative approach to the impact of rate hikes. And we're considering to make the statement that we're going to stay focus on improving our efficiency ratio. Now in fairness, it grinds down slow. So there's no doubt about that. I mean, we've got sort of junk and it crack down slower. But we are not back tacking off, we are not wavering or anything like as of the commitment to continue to improve on the efficiency side.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, in terms of some of the things that we continue to work on expenses, to be clear, we are not saying that we're taking our foot off the gas pedal on managing expenses. And we're still looking at overall operations costs, we're looking at causes, lend
componenttext: Mike, in terms of some of the things that we continue to work on expenses, to be clear, we are not saying that we're taking our foot off the gas pedal on managing expenses. And we're still looking at overall operations costs, we're looking at causes, lending centers. We're still looking at technology infrastructure and how we can continue to improve our efficiency there. I mentioned that we introduced a new mortgage origination platform late in 2015, and I anticipate that, that'll help our overall efficiency and effectiveness within the mortgage segment. I mentioned we continue to work on optimizing our real estate footprint, and we'll continue to do that now through '18 and '19, I expect. And look, across the whole company, we're staying disciplined on how we manage roles, responsibilities and we have a very clear pay-for-performance philosophy. I think that shows up for -- across our teammate profile and, of course, we continue to consolidate our suppliers. So we're working on managing our third-parties apply your profile. So none of this is meant to say that hey, we are declaring victory on expenses. What we're saying is that as we move forward, the big rocks on expenses, I think, we've achieved and we are going to be more balanced to a going forward in terms of revenue growth and expense management.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Marlin Mosby of Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Marlin Mosby of Vining Sparks.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aleem, I want to ask you on your guidance on net interest margin. I think that's a little inconsistent, so I just want to make sure we connect the dot's right. You came into the year in first quarter of '15, you had a 2 83 margin, which improved to 2 98 b
componenttext: Aleem, I want to ask you on your guidance on net interest margin. I think that's a little inconsistent, so I just want to make sure we connect the dot's right. You came into the year in first quarter of '15, you had a 2 83 margin, which improved to 2 98 by the time you get to the end of the year, which would have averaged 2 90, you're saying you're going to improve 3 to 5 basis points in the first quarter. And so when you're looking at that kind of trend, your net interest margin would have to be significantly be above the 2016 versus 2015 unless it's going downward from first quarter through the end of 2016?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right, Marlin, that's exactly what I was trying to say -- I'm sorry, if I was unclear. I do expect...
componenttext: That's right, Marlin, that's exactly what I was trying to say -- I'm sorry, if I was unclear. I do expect...

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little more flat year-to-year, which you really got a already a lot of improvement in there. I'm also wondering about you said if you had another rate hike in the middle of the year, if you wouldn't see the margin improve over the first quarter, wh
componenttext: It's a little more flat year-to-year, which you really got a already a lot of improvement in there. I'm also wondering about you said if you had another rate hike in the middle of the year, if you wouldn't see the margin improve over the first quarter, when you're already getting some benefit from rising interest rates, there would be seems like another catalyst for margins to go up again on that next, just one more rate hike in the middle of the year?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do think that will help. So to be clear on my margin expectations, Marty, I think the first quarter margin will go up from the fourth quarter. And I think that's sort of 3 to 5 basis points or so. And then, from there, for the rest of the year, I'm expe
componenttext: I do think that will help. So to be clear on my margin expectations, Marty, I think the first quarter margin will go up from the fourth quarter. And I think that's sort of 3 to 5 basis points or so. And then, from there, for the rest of the year, I'm expecting it to be generally stable through the first quarter number, to the increased higher-margin level, assuming we get that one rate hike in the middle of the year. The offset to that, so that's -- the rate hike is going to be healthful and we're asset-sensitive. And we're asset sensitive actually at every key rate duration point across the curve. So that will be helpful. The offset to that is competitive pressures are still strong. Spreads continue to be tight if anything, grinding maybe at a bit tighter but sort of kind of stabilizing a little bit relative to the decline we saw in spreads over the last year. And we still have old mortgage and old securities that will continue to roll off the books that will have to reinvest that new lower rates. So there are mitigants to the rate rise, which I think will put a cap on margins. But I do think year-over-year, margin will be higher and Q1 to Q4 margin will be higher.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up on asset quality side, you're talking about being conservative in a sense that you've got performing loans that somehow you're pushing into nonperforming. I didn't really have any foreshadowing of this in the delinquencies. Can you give
componenttext: And as a follow-up on asset quality side, you're talking about being conservative in a sense that you've got performing loans that somehow you're pushing into nonperforming. I didn't really have any foreshadowing of this in the delinquencies. Can you give us some feel for the migration of how $200 million ended up in nonperforming this particular quarter and your thought process around that deterioration?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question, Marty. We're trying to be careful here. The majority of the loans we put into nonperforming are actually still performing today. They are performing loans, but these are loans that when we look at her those particular clients
componenttext: Yes, thanks for the question, Marty. We're trying to be careful here. The majority of the loans we put into nonperforming are actually still performing today. They are performing loans, but these are loans that when we look at her those particular clients, we think that there is a risk that they will become nonperforming, some time in the next couple of years if oil sales where it is. Remember how quickly this move has been on oil, right? And so it's only 15 months ago, we were at $100 a barrel. So the move has been very, very rapid, and we're just trying to make sure that we try and stay ahead of this, so that we don't end up surprising you and ourselves later.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

componenttext: Going back to energy, sorry. The -- regarding the increase in the NPS, can you just tell us what types of credits they were or are the E&P or service that went on to NPA? Also worried the national credits? Andy have the average size of the credits that moved on or the number?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then the nonenergy or the nonoil field service and non-E&P types of loans of that you're including in that energy-related classification, what is that? Is that utilities and coal?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's mostly midstream and downstream. So when you look at the midstream and downstream, that makes up the remainder of what we call the energy book and when you think about what lower oil prices do for midstream, it's sort of a nonevent. And for downstr
componenttext: That's mostly midstream and downstream. So when you look at the midstream and downstream, that makes up the remainder of what we call the energy book and when you think about what lower oil prices do for midstream, it's sort of a nonevent. And for downstream, it's actually beneficial and so for our downstream clients, the decrease in energy prices will help them.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then lastly, also within the energy topic. Do you have your total credit size ratio within your energy portfolio? And then also a much of your energy book is investment-grade versus noninvestment-grade?
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then lastly, also within the energy topic. Do you have your total credit size ratio within your energy portfolio? And then also a much of your energy book is investment-grade versus noninvestment-grade?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, John, so let me answer those backwards. So investment-grade versus noninvestment-grade, I don't have that exact number in front of me, but as you would expect, we have a relatively high -- higher proportion than others of investment-grade, so think
componenttext: Well, John, so let me answer those backwards. So investment-grade versus noninvestment-grade, I don't have that exact number in front of me, but as you would expect, we have a relatively high -- higher proportion than others of investment-grade, so think about the context maybe of a third to half of our book would actually be investment grade. And as you would also expect when you think about a conservative underwriter like SunTrust, that criticized portion would be a relatively low and for us, that's on the order of 20%.

componenttext: And then lastly, the first lien versus second lien, do you have that?

componenttext: The vast majority of our loans are first lien. The vast, vast, vast majority of our loans are first lien.
