headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christine. Good morning, and welcome to SunTrust's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Thanks for joining us. In addition to today's press release, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during ou
componenttext: Thank you, Christine. Good morning, and welcome to SunTrust's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Thanks for joining us. In addition to today's press release, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press release, presentation and detailed financial schedules can be accessed at investors.suntrust.com. With me today, among other members of our executive management team, are Bill Rogers, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Aleem Gillani, our Chief Financial Officer. Before we get started, I need to remind you that our comments today may include forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainty, and actual results could differ materially. We list the factors that might cause actual results to differ materially in our SEC filings, which are also available on our website. During the call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures when talking about the company's performance. You may find the reconciliation of these measures to GAAP financial measures in our press release and on our website, investors.suntrust.com. Finally, SunTrust is not responsible for and does not edit nor guarantee the accuracy of our earnings teleconference transcripts provided by third parties. The only authorize live and archived webcasts are located on our website. With that, I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, thank, Ankur, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin with a brief overview of the quarter, and then I'm going to turn it over to Aleem for some additional details, including our results at the business segment level. I'll conclude with some p
componenttext:
All right, thank, Ankur, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin with a brief overview of the quarter, and then I'm going to turn it over to Aleem for some additional details, including our results at the business segment level. I'll conclude with some perspectives on how this quarter's performance fits into our long-term strategy and overall investment thesis. To start, I'm pleased with the results we deliver this quarter. For several years, we've been on a path to grow and diversify the business, improve profitability and increase our capital return to shareholders. This quarter, you saw our continued progress in each of these areas, specifically our ongoing commitment to invest in revenue growth opportunities, while also tightly managing expenses resulted in solid improvements in efficiency. Additionally, as most of you are aware, the Federal Reserve did not object to our 2016 capital plan, which calls for a 23% increase in total capital return relative to our 2015 plan. This is a result of our strong capital position and improved financial performance and demonstrates our commitment to returning capital to our shareholders. 
So getting into the specifics, we reported $0.94 of earnings per share this quarter, which included certain discrete items that netted to a $0.05 benefit to the bottom line but which did not meaningfully impact the current quarter's efficiency ratio. Aleem will provide some more detail on these items later but thematically, they help better position our company for the future, particularly as it relates to optimizing our branch delivery network. Excluding these items and the $0.03 of discrete tax benefits from a year ago, EPS increased 3%, a solid performance, particularly given the $120 million year-over-year increase in loan loss provision. This performance was supported by strong revenue growth, as total revenues grew 6% sequentially and 7% year-over-year. The sequential improvement was driven by higher noninterest income and the year-over-year improvement was driven largely by increased net interest income, reflecting the diversity of our business model. This revenue growth, combined with tightly controlled expenses, resulted in a 60.1% tangible efficiency ratio this quarter, a meaningful improvement compared to both prior quarter and prior year. 
Net interest income was up slightly compared to the first quarter, as solid loan growth offset the 5 basis point decline in NIM. Noninterest income was up nearly $120 million sequentially, reflecting the strong execution in both favorable and volatile markets by our mortgage and investment banking teams. Average loan and deposit growth this quarter was 2% and 3%, respectively, driven by solid economic conditions in our markets, combined with the onboard investments we've made and continue to make in our businesses. As anticipated, we continue to resolve problem energy credits, which drove the 40 basis point sequential increase in net charge-offs and the 3 basis point decline in the NPL ratio. 
Outside of energy, asset quality remains very strong, as evidenced by only 19 basis points of net charge-offs for the rest of the bank. Tangible book value per share increased 3% sequentially and 12% from the prior year and our fully phased-in Basel III Common Equity Tier 1 ratio declined slightly to 9.7%, all reflective of continued improvements in profitability, combined with effective capital deployment. The course we've set has us performing at a high level and will continue to for propel us into the future. So with that as a quick overview, let me turn it over Aleem to provide more details on this quarter's performance.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us this morning, particularly if you were up last night watching the convention. Let's move on to slide 4 and taking a look at that slide, you'll see that our net interest margin declined 5 basi
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us this morning, particularly if you were up last night watching the convention. Let's move on to slide 4 and taking a look at that slide, you'll see that our net interest margin declined 5 basis points, primarily due to lower earning asset yields, as the decline in long-term rates increased premium amortization expense and the low level of absolute rates lowered reinvestment rates across multiple asset classes. In addition, increased long-term debt, combined with slightly higher deposit costs contributed to 2 basis points of the sequential decline. However, net interest income increased $6 million from the prior quarter, as a solid 2% average loan growth counteracted the reduction in NIM. Assuming the static rate environment, we expect the net interest margin to decline a further 3 to 5 basis points next quarter. This potential decline is more than we previously anticipated, largely due to the significant flattening of the yield curve over the past few months. 
We are continuing to carefully manage the duration of the balance sheet given the prolonged low rate environment, while also being cognizant of controlling interest rate risk. 
Moving to Slide 5. Noninterest income increased $117 million sequentially, driven by mortgage, which benefited from lower rates, other noninterest income and capital markets. Mortgage production income increased $51 million, benefiting from strong increases in both purchase and refinancing activity. In addition, we simplified our product offering to include upfront origination fees in the all-in loan yield rather than as a separate fee. This change modestly impacts the timing of revenue recognition and increased this quarter's mortgage production income by approximately $10 million. Other noninterest income increased $37 million, primarily due to a gain associated with the sale-leaseback of one of our office buildings, which further supports our strategy to reduce our real estate footprint and provides us with increased flexibility in the future.
Investment banking had a strong quarter, with revenues increasing $28 million, as we continued to see the combination of our long-term investments and strategy to deliver solid results for our clients and shareholders. Partially offsetting this increase was a $21 million decrease in trading income, which was largely driven by higher CVA costs, due both to a change in our methodology for calculating counterparty reserves for derivatives and as a result of lower rates. Client-related transaction fees, which includes service charges, card fees and other fees, increased $25 million from the prior quarter, not only due to typical seasonal patterns but also due to an increase in loan commitment fees in STRH associated with M&A-related bridge financing. Separately as a reminder, once we fully implement our enhanced posting order process in Q4 of this year, we will see a reduction in service charges of approximately $10 million per quarter. Let's move on to expenses.
Noninterest expense increased $27 million relative to the prior quarter, primarily due to discrete charges associated with ongoing efficiency initiatives. These charges were recorded in other noninterest expense and are generally associated with our ongoing branch network optimization efforts. While the savings from these efforts will not be material in the context of our total expense base, they will help continue to make us a more effective company. In addition, FDIC premium and regulatory exam expenses increased $8 million due to higher assessment fees, primarily due to a growing deposit base and a higher assessment rate, the latter of which is mostly due to the increase in nonperforming energy loans in recent quarters. As a reminder, assessment costs will increase an additional $10 million in the third quarter as a result of the FDIC's new surcharge. Partially offsetting these increases were lower employee compensation expenses, marketing expenses and net occupancy expenses, the latter of which included $6 million of discrete benefits. In comparison to the second quarter of last year, noninterest expense was up 1%, largely due to the same discrete charges.
As you can see on Slide 7, the tangible efficiency ratio was 60.1% in the second quarter, an improvement of 350 basis points year-over-year as revenue growth exceeded expense growth. While this quarter's performance was strong, we do not believe a 60% efficiency ratio is our new run rate for the remainder of this year. With that said, our year-to-date progress keeps us on track to meet our objective of improving efficiency ratio for the fifth consecutive year.
The continued low interest rate environment will clearly impact our go-forward trajectory. However, we remain committed to maintaining strong expense discipline and achieving our long-term goal of a sub-60% efficiency ratio. 
Turning to Slide 8, asset quality trends were generally similar to previous quarters, with the divergence between energy and nonenergy-related performance. Excluding energy, our loan portfolio continues to perform very well, evidenced by charge-offs of only 19 basis points in the second quarter and stable to slightly improving delinquency levels. With respect to energy, we charged off $70 million of loans and our nonperforming loans declined from $420 million to $354 million. The total criticized ratio, which includes nonaccrual loans and criticized accruing loans, remained relatively stable at 30%.
Total ALLL for the company was relatively flat from the prior quarter as growth in the total loan portfolio was offset by continued improvements in the asset quality of our residential loan portfolio. Total provision expense increased $45 million compared to the first quarter, primarily due to the energy charge-offs. From here, and assuming no significant changes in the macroeconomic environment, we expect NPL levels to decline as we resolve existing energy NPLs. We continue to expect the company's overall net charge-off ratio to be between 30 and 40 basis points for the full year 2016. We expect our allowance to be relatively stable in the near term, which should result in a provision expense that approximates net charge-offs. In addition, we expect energy charge-offs to abate as we move through the remainder of 2016 and thus, we do expect the total provision expense to decline relative to the second quarter level.
Let's turn to balance sheet trends. Average performing loans increased 2% from the prior quarter, with broad-based growth across most portfolios. Commercial loan growth was driven by C&I and commercial construction, while consumer loan growth was generally broad-based. Our Consumer Lending strategies continued to produce profitable growth through each of our major channels. In addition, our overall lending pipelines and dialogue with clients continue to be solid, which we believe is reflective of a steady U.S. economy. On a year-over-year basis, average performing loans grew $8.1 billion or 6%, driven by 5% growth in C&I and 15% growth in total consumer loans and was partially offset by declines in home equity and payoffs in commercial real estate. 
Turning to Slide 10, average client deposits increased 3% compared to the prior quarter and 8% year-over-year, partially due to a large temporary deposit associated with a client-related M&A transaction but largely due to core growth across most products and businesses. Period-end deposits were stable sequentially, given typical seasonal patterns from Q1 to Q2. Over the past 2 years, client deposits are up 15%. This success is the result of our increased focus on meeting more of our clients' deposit and payment needs, our investment in technology platforms and ultimately, our teammates in both the Consumer and Private Wealth and Wholesale segments. Rates paid on deposits increased 1 basis point sequentially, a lag effect of the December rate increase. We continue to maintain a disciplined approach to pricing, with a focus on maximizing the value proposition outside the rate paid for our clients. 
Slide 11 provides an update on our capital positions. As Bill noted, the Federal Reserve did not object to the capital plan we submitted in conjunction with the 2016 CCAR process, and our relative performance within that bank group continues to be strong. This is most notably evidenced by SunTrust's continuing to have amongst the lowest levels of loan losses and capital erosion in a severely adverse economic scenario, relative to other CCAR banks. This progress reflects the significant and cumulative actions we've taken over the past 5 years to de-risk our balance sheet and improve the quality of new loan production. The capital plan includes a share buyback program of up to $960 million over the coming 4 quarters. In addition, we will increase our common stock dividend from $0.24 to $0.26, subject to board approval. In total, this represents a 23% increase in total capital return to shareholders relative to our previous plan. Alongside our increases in capital return, we've also organically added approximately $500 million of Common Equity Tier 1 over the past year and maintained strong capital levels, evidenced by a 9.7% fully phased-in Basel III Common Equity Tier 1 ratio. Tangible book value per share was up 3% sequentially and up 12% compared to the prior year, driven by growth in retained earnings and higher AOCI as a result of lower long-term interest rates. Lastly, our liquidity coverage ratio exceeds current regulatory requirements and we added approximately $1 billion to our securities portfolio and the second quarter to make further progress toward the increased 2017 requirements. 
Moving to the segment overviews, we'll, begin with Consumer Banking and Private Wealth Management on Slide 12. Net income declined $10 million sequentially and $38 million compared to the prior year, driven primarily by a higher provision expense and discrete expenses recognized in the current quarter. On a year-over-year basis, net income trends were also negatively impacted by lower Wealth Management-related income. Net interest income was stable sequentially and was up 4% versus the prior year, as a result of strong loan and deposit growth, which more than offsets the lower net interest margin. Our consumer direct lending businesses continue to exhibit strong momentum. Specifically, average balances are up $2.7 billion or 26% year-over-year as a result of the investments we have made, in addition to market share gains we've been able to take in certain businesses resulting from our strong and stable funding base. 
Further, our emphasis on deepening client relationships has driven strong deposit growth, up 4% sequentially and 6% versus the prior year. Some of this growth is due to the large temporary client deposit I mentioned earlier, but the majority of it reflects our emphasis on delivering the bank's full capabilities to all of our clients. 
Both the solid loan and deposit growth trends in CPWM over the past couple of years reflect the increased momentum this business has created in acquiring new clients and deepening existing relationships. Noninterest income was up 3% sequentially and down 6% year-over-year. The sequential increase was driven by higher transaction-related fees due to increased consumer activity and normal seasonality. The year-over-year decline was a driven by lower Wealth Management-related revenue, which has been pressured by lower assets under management and heightened market volatility. Noninterest expense increased 2% and 4% on a sequential and year-over-year basis, respectively. These increases were primarily driven by discrete charges in the current quarter related to our branch network optimization efforts, which I discussed earlier in the presentation. Optimizing our network continues to be a critical strategic priority so that we continue to serve our clients when, where and how they want to do business.
In conjunction with branch optimization, profitably growing our Consumer Lending and Wealth Management business remains a primary focus in this segment. Executing these priorities should result in steady improvements in both efficiency and the client experience over time. 
Moving to Wholesale Banking, increased credit costs continue to put some downward pressure on net income, but overall client activity levels and market share continue to improve. Revenues were up 1% sequentially, due entirely to higher investment banking income. Within investment banking, we had a record quarter in both investment-grade bonds and equity originations. The growth of both of these businesses is a strong reflection of the continued strategic investments we've made in recent years. As an example, we increased the number of publishing equity research analysts by 30% over the past 2 years. And as a result of our broker rankings, have improved -- as a result, our broker rankings have improved and our equity-related revenue is growing.
Offsetting the increase in investment banking income was a $20 million sequential decline in trading income. The vast majority of this decline was driven by the higher CVA costs I discussed earlier, and excluding this, we would characterize core client trading activity in the second quarter as solid. 
Moving to the Mortgage segment, which was a key contributor to our performance this quarter, noninterest income increased $41 million sequentially and $60 million year-over-year. Sequential increase was driven entirely by production income, which was up $51 million as a result of greater purchase and refinancing activity, in addition to higher gain-on-sale margins. As anticipated, servicing income declined $10 million sequentially, as a result of the increased decay expense related to elevated refinancing activity. This was partially offset by additional servicing fees, driven by growth in the servicing portfolio. On a year-over-year basis, servicing income increased $22 million due to improved hedge performance and a 6% increase in the size of our service for others portfolio. These increases in noninterest income, combined with strong expense management, drove the $19 million sequential and $6 million year-over-year increase in the bottom line.
Looking to the next quarter, pipelines and application activity points to continued positive momentum in mortgage production volumes in response to the low rate environment. While we do not expect to match this quarter's results, mortgage production income should demonstrate meaningful improvement relative to the third quarter of last year. At a higher level, we continue to be pleased with the increased consistency, improved execution and targeted growth the mortgage business is delivering to our clients and shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Bill to provide some concluding perspectives.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, thanks, Aleem. So to conclude, I'm going to point to Slide 15, which highlights how this quarter's performance aligns with our overall investment thesis and the strategies we have in place. So first, the diversity of our business model helped
componenttext:
Okay, great, thanks, Aleem. So to conclude, I'm going to point to Slide 15, which highlights how this quarter's performance aligns with our overall investment thesis and the strategies we have in place. So first, the diversity of our business model helped us mitigate risk and achieve 7% year-over-year revenue growth. We delivered good revenue momentum across both net interest income and noninterest income and across all 3 major business segments. In addition, our businesses are working better to deliver the entire bank to our clients. 
Second, our profitability continues to improve as a result of our commitment to tightly manage expenses and drive positive operating leverage. We've improved the year-to-date efficiency ratio relative to 2015, putting as well on track to meet our commitment to improve efficiency on an annual basis for the fifth consecutive year. Third, we've been using many of these efficiency gains to fund growth investments in the company. So as an example, this quarter was our second best quarter ever for investment banking. We're particularly encouraged by the growth of our core advisory businesses, which take a long time to develop and are the product of over 10 years of investment. Today, equity and M&A-related revenue account for 39% of investment banking income, which was our highest percentage ever. 
In Mortgage, we've been making targeted investments in both people and technology, which has resulted in solid growth and allows us to capitalize on the current market conditions. Similarly, Consumer Lending has been another key area of investment for the last few years and is demonstrating strong, consistent momentum. Also, our investments in Consumer Banking, Private Wealth Management and Treasury & Payments Solutions are yielding strong results, with more clients entrusting their deposit and wealth with SunTrust. And lastly, our strong capital position has afforded us the opportunity to grow capital returns and reduce our share count, giving our long-term shareholders a higher ownership stake each quarter.
Now, I'd be remiss not to acknowledge the continued low-rate environment, which will place pressure on net interest income and profitability trajectory, even though in the near term, it should be a tailwind to mortgage production and capital markets revenue and we are well positioned there. However, the low interest rate pressure is applicable to the entire industry, and I'm confident if we continue to execute our strategy, fulfill our purpose of lighting the way to financial well-being for our clients, SunTrust will continue to sustain our outperformance. Now with that, I'll turn the call back over to Ankur and I believe we'll begin the Q&A.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Thanks, Bill. Christine, we're now ready to begin the Q&A portion of the call. [Operator Instructions].

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from John McDonald of Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from John McDonald of Bernstein.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill just mentioned the challenge of the low-rate environment, Aleem, can you give a little bit more color on the NIM outlook you mentioned, 3 to 5 basis points next quarter in a flat-rate environment? Just walk us through the drivers of that and do you s
componenttext: Bill just mentioned the challenge of the low-rate environment, Aleem, can you give a little bit more color on the NIM outlook you mentioned, 3 to 5 basis points next quarter in a flat-rate environment? Just walk us through the drivers of that and do you still think you could grow net interest income dollars from the 2Q level, what's the degree of difficulty of growing NII from here?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, John. Yes, if you recall at the start of the year, our view on rates overall was that we were only expecting one interest rate hike in 2016. And we expected that in the latter part of the year. Now with the impact of the low -- in the U.K, ob
componenttext: Yes, thanks, John. Yes, if you recall at the start of the year, our view on rates overall was that we were only expecting one interest rate hike in 2016. And we expected that in the latter part of the year. Now with the impact of the low -- in the U.K, obviously, that rate hike looks like it's going to be less probable than we had originally anticipated. As a result, if we think about the drivers of NIM from here, we are expecting NIM to grind down a little bit in Q3, perhaps a little bit more in Q4. The main drivers of that would be new production yields across many of our portfolios are still a little bit lower than current portfolio levels. Another driver would be that we continue to build our securities portfolio to prepare for 2017 LCR requirements. So for those two reasons, NIM may continued to decline a little bit. But if you think about the last few years on net interest income, what you've seen with us, John, is that we've been able to use growth in loan and deposits to offset the declines in NIM over the last several years, right? Even though our NIM has dropped about 30, 35 basis points over the last few years, net interest income for us has been until last year, very flat. In the last year, with the growth in NIM, we were able to achieve net interest income really took off and we run a very steep upward sloping trajectory. From here on, with NIM starting to decline again, we do think that with the loan and deposit growth we've got, we will be able to grow net interest again. However, I'd say that it's going to be at a relatively low pace.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: I think about half of the net charge-offs this quarter for the related to energy and you talked about them moderating going forward. Any estimate on how much energy loss in total is left if oil prices stay around here?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, if I take a look at what our energy charges has been over the last 3 quarters, they've been about $90 million so far over three quarters. If I take a look at the profile that we've got in the book now, how good that looks and of course, as you
componenttext: Yes, Matt, if I take a look at what our energy charges has been over the last 3 quarters, they've been about $90 million so far over three quarters. If I take a look at the profile that we've got in the book now, how good that looks and of course, as you know, the majority of our energy book is actually downstream and midstream as opposed to upstream in oil field services, I think we're about halfway through or perhaps more than halfway through in terms of energy charge-offs. And what comes in terms of new energy charge-offs from here might come over the course of the next 3 or 4 quarters. So that's why I expect to see declining energy charge-offs from here and therefore, a decline in our provision expense from Q2.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, just cost of consumer portfolios, I think the delinquencies were stable there. But how are the auto portfolio, the online lending subsidiary you have, how are some of those businesses performing?
componenttext: And as a follow-up, just cost of consumer portfolios, I think the delinquencies were stable there. But how are the auto portfolio, the online lending subsidiary you have, how are some of those businesses performing?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you know, Matt, I think they're -- remember, our portfolio is a prime to superprime portfolio, both in the auto as well as in, and particularly in the online portfolio. So the order book has continued to perform well, 40 basis points of charge-offs a
componenttext: Yes, you know, Matt, I think they're -- remember, our portfolio is a prime to superprime portfolio, both in the auto as well as in, and particularly in the online portfolio. So the order book has continued to perform well, 40 basis points of charge-offs and early-stage below 90 and those are low points, I mean, they're low relative to historical numbers. But we've stressed this portfolio. We've looked at it hard, we've looked at used car values and all the things that could happen to the portfolio and feel good about where we're positioned. Again, we don't do subprime auto, so we sort of stayed at different places as it relates to that and then as it relates to the LightStream business and GreenSky, I mean, remember again, superprime business, FICO scores 750 to 770, on the high end of the range and similarly there, we're seeing continued strong credit performance. Consumer's in good shape, I mean, particularly the prime in the superprime level. All throughout our portfolio, Consumer's in good shape.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Mr. Kenneth Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: Next question is from Mr. Kenneth Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe you talked about that, the second half efficiency ratio might not stay down around the 60% level, the strong performance you had this quarter. Typically, you guys tend to have lower expenses in the second half. So I'm just wondering, why can't i
componenttext: I believe you talked about that, the second half efficiency ratio might not stay down around the 60% level, the strong performance you had this quarter. Typically, you guys tend to have lower expenses in the second half. So I'm just wondering, why can't it stay down here? And I'll throw my follow-up in there, is there something about your expected fees that perhaps you'll see a drip up from the current quarter performance?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ken, I think you've partially answered your question. Yes, I think ther are several things why the efficiency ratio maybe a little bit higher in the second half than it was in this quarter. One, obviously, the NIM decline is going to put -- is goi
componenttext: Thanks, Ken, I think you've partially answered your question. Yes, I think ther are several things why the efficiency ratio maybe a little bit higher in the second half than it was in this quarter. One, obviously, the NIM decline is going to put -- is going to have downward pressure on net interest income and we're going to be working hard to grow net interest income from here. But we know we've got some increased expenses coming up in the second half. FDIC assessment fees will go up $10 million a quarter starting in Q3. We've got -- remember we've got our posting order change coming in Q4, which will probably reduce our fee income by about $10 million a quarter starting in Q4. And then typically for us, outside processing and software is on a normal seasonal basis, it's normally a bit higher in the second half than it is in the first half as new applications come online over the course of the year and we start amortizing some of that cost. So for those reasons, I think the overall efficiency ratio maybe a little bit higher in the second half than in Q2, but year-over-year, I think is the big key. We know, and we've always targeted it the last 4 years, targeted improved efficiency year-over-year. So we've not actually focused on it much on an individual quarter basis. Our intent is to continue to make this company more effective and more efficient in the current year than it was in the past year and more effective and more efficient in the next year than it was this year. So this year, we still do expect to beat our efficiency ratio from last year and then we're going to be looking to see how we can continue to improve next year.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken. This is Bill. I want to be clear a couple of things I mean, we, obviously don't annualize one quarter from an efficiency ratio, even if it's high, if it's low, we look at some of that annualized run rate and as Aleem said, we're committed to con
componenttext: Yes, Ken. This is Bill. I want to be clear a couple of things I mean, we, obviously don't annualize one quarter from an efficiency ratio, even if it's high, if it's low, we look at some of that annualized run rate and as Aleem said, we're committed to continue to make improvements but we did get a taste of it and when we sort of like it. So I want to be clear that to our intensity is at a very, very high level related to our efficiency ratio. We're not slacking off one single bit.

componenttext: First, on the loan front, I just wonder if you can give a little bit of color into the C&I growth or the C&I trends in the quarter and on an end of period basis, it looks like your C&I loans were down. So I'm not sure if that's energy or whatnot. So if you could just talk about that a little bit and then also your appetite to grow commercial real estate here. I just wanted to get your thoughts there.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- as we've said many times, we're careful not to manage to loan growth. So what I look at is I look at production and then I look at loan sales and paydowns and then I look at utilization. So utilization was actually up, just to give a little
componenttext: Yes, let me -- as we've said many times, we're careful not to manage to loan growth. So what I look at is I look at production and then I look at loan sales and paydowns and then I look at utilization. So utilization was actually up, just to give a little data point. And generally, I'll talk a lot about utilization because it goes quarter-after-quarter, but this was the highest point in the last 7 yes, almost 8 quarters. So it's worth noting that's not a lot, but it's worth noting. Our production numbers for the quarter were actually really good. As a matter of fact, it was one of our higher quarters from a production standpoint but we also got a little bit of increase in paydowns. So that sort got of the net-net part of that. The C&I portfolio year-over-year has got great growth and again, quarter to quarter, we're sort of careful about that year-over-year as you know, good solid double-digit growth in C&I loans. As it relates to CRE, I think I said this before, we -- on the production side, we're that. I mean that's somewhat market-driven and somewhat driven by our own desires. But outstandings are going to go up a little bit and I think that will trend that way for several quarters as the velocity of construction loans sort of stay on the books a little bit longer, by the way which we're happy with high-quality, will under within. We're happy with but the best velocity of giving those have the books are going to slow a little bit. And part of that, you saw sort of in those production numbers I talked about.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: Got it, got it. That's helpful. One last thing, Bill, to flip over to the capital front, I heard you discuss your deployment plans. In terms of M&A, I just wanted to get your updated thoughts there.  I mean you're one of the few larger banks that can actually do some deals here. But I wanted to get your thoughts on your interest in the whole bank M&A and even nonbank?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, yes, we've been really clear on that. The bank we like the most is SunTrust and you can see the investments we've been making in our company and I would conclude that in the last several years, this they will not of a lot about small bank acq
componenttext: Yes. I mean, yes, we've been really clear on that. The bank we like the most is SunTrust and you can see the investments we've been making in our company and I would conclude that in the last several years, this they will not of a lot about small bank acquisitions in terms of investment in our own company. And we like that best. So whole bank M&A really is not a primary focus for us at this particular juncture. On the nonbank side, I mean, we continue to be interested. We continue to think that there are opportunities there, generally things that would be fee income-oriented, things that would be accretive to our strategies and accretive to our KPIs fast would be the type of priorities.

And I'm wondering if you could give us some insight on how much progress you think you can achieve on efficiency improvement beyond 2016 without any assistance from rates? headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Erika, overall, as you know, we continue to try to grow -- or improve the efficiency of the company overall. We are working on several ways to continue to do this. We don't really focus on sort of specific expense control programs. The sporadic, int
componenttext: Well, Erika, overall, as you know, we continue to try to grow -- or improve the efficiency of the company overall. We are working on several ways to continue to do this. We don't really focus on sort of specific expense control programs. The sporadic, intermittent programs don't tend, we think, to build a culture of continuous improvement. And I think what we like about our teammates at SunTrust is that we do have a culture of continuous improvement to try to manage expenses and improve efficiencies of the company overall in every segment. And we continue to look at several ways to continue to do that. We are looking at operations costs, at improving our use of technology overall. We're continuing to work to optimize our real estate footprint. You saw a little bit about this quarter with the sale-leaseback of one particular asset. We're being very disciplined in how we manage roles and responsibilities, staffing and we're looking at that across -- we're looking at these things as well as supplier management, the number of vendors we have across every one of our segments, including CPWM. And within Consumer Banking and Private Wealth, we're looking at several ways we can continue to grow and improve our efficiency there, including adding revenue and adding frontline-facing teammates who can improve our efficiency ratio actually by growing revenue. So we've got several initiatives underway as part of an overall continuous improvement approach.

componenttext: Yes, I'll say not more much more guidance. We would expect the efficiency to continue to improve the respective level of rates long term. That slope may change but we would expect that to continue to improve.

componenttext: A couple of clarifications, Bill and Aleem. One thing, so just looking at the absolute level of expenses in the past, you've given some guidance on it, but $10 million increase in the FDIC assessment fees and obviously, up and down based on incentive-driven revenues. Other than that, anything else from the -- and obviously we take out the noncore items you highlighted this quarter. Taking all that out, anything else we should be mindful of as we think about that line?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Vivek, if you're asking about sort of core expenses and revenues relative to what we pointed out, no. I think what we tried to do here is be very, very transparent with you as to all of the noncore items that affected us this quarter. You saw them on t
componenttext: So Vivek, if you're asking about sort of core expenses and revenues relative to what we pointed out, no. I think what we tried to do here is be very, very transparent with you as to all of the noncore items that affected us this quarter. You saw them on the major items on the first page of the deck. As you say, I talked about a couple of the minor items that we see coming up. So I think you've got -- you've got all the information that we can provide on what the core earnings power of the company is likely to be over the course of the next little while. And I think the one point I would reiterate is from a provision expense, with everything that we're seeing today, I do expect that to decline as we go forward from today.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. One more, different topic. Dividend payout, Bill and -- if you can give us some as to how you're thinking about that. You've got a dividend increase, but are you still below some of your regional peers are any thoughts on that?
componenttext: Great. One more, different topic. Dividend payout, Bill and -- if you can give us some as to how you're thinking about that. You've got a dividend increase, but are you still below some of your regional peers are any thoughts on that?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We set out on a course similar to the efficiency ratio to say we want to continue to improve our return to shareholders, and we've done that consistently. We've gone from the 60s to the 80s in terms of total return, and we've said long term, that's s
componenttext: Yes. We set out on a course similar to the efficiency ratio to say we want to continue to improve our return to shareholders, and we've done that consistently. We've gone from the 60s to the 80s in terms of total return, and we've said long term, that's sort of in the zone that we want to be in. All that against the backdrop of a really good strong capital level. So I think just on a net basis, we would continue the same story of the efficiency ratio, we continue to improve our return to shareholders. That return and probably improvement will be at a smaller slope but I think still we have an opportunity to increase the return.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Vivek, we had a pretty clear choice in our planned submission this year as to how we could choose to improve the dividend or payouts overall. We chose to do it in a balanced way with some dividend increase and some repurchase increase. But as you poin
componenttext: And Vivek, we had a pretty clear choice in our planned submission this year as to how we could choose to improve the dividend or payouts overall. We chose to do it in a balanced way with some dividend increase and some repurchase increase. But as you point out, we did lean more towards repurchase. And that made a lot of sense to us in the context of a stock price that was only around 1.3x tangible book. So at that kind of level, it makes sense for us to increase the repurchase more than the dividend. And every year as we submit our plan, we'll be looking at what those numbers look like, and we also took feedback from our -- many of our largest shareholders as to what their preferences were. So we incorporated that within the plan and we intend to continue to do that.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Marlin Mosby of Vining Sparks.
componenttext: Next question is from Marlin Mosby of Vining Sparks.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aleem, I wanted to -- and this is more just a calculation but when you did your efficiency ratio, I believe the way that you did it if I look back in the appendix was you left in the gains in the charges, so I don't know that you exclude those. If you inc
componenttext: Aleem, I wanted to -- and this is more just a calculation but when you did your efficiency ratio, I believe the way that you did it if I look back in the appendix was you left in the gains in the charges, so I don't know that you exclude those. If you included them, which it looks like you did, they had actually a positive effect on your efficiency ratio this particular quarter. So just those unusual items rolling off would actually round you from 60 up to 61. Just wanted to make sure I looked at that right.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Marty, you're looking at that right. We didn't make an adjustment for these items. They weren't really very substantial. They weren't material enough, for example for us to go out and release an 8-K on them. But we just wanted to be very transparent
componenttext: Yes, Marty, you're looking at that right. We didn't make an adjustment for these items. They weren't really very substantial. They weren't material enough, for example for us to go out and release an 8-K on them. But we just wanted to be very transparent with everybody on here's our core items, here's our noncore items, you can choose to make whatever calculation you want. But we try to show you everything that was core and noncore so that you get a sense of what the real underlying earnings power of SunTrust is and how it can grow. And then you could make adjustments as you see fit. We tried to give you the adjustments we thought made sense.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: No, I was just trying to highlight that that has a 1% rounding up, so not really an operational or a pressure just as you move forward you don't have those unusual gains still left in the numbers. The other thing I wanted to ask you if you look at the asset quality, the charge-offs in the back in the fourth quarter was the nonperformers going up and then now you're charging off these energy loans. Your exposure looks on the surface to be better positioned, but it looks like you had a couple of larger loans that you were dealing with and have been dealing with through this process. Do you feel like you're getting through the process of dealing with those particular loans such that the underlying strength of the portfolio will eventually start to show through here?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marty, that's a very insightful question on the bones of our portfolio and I think you nailed it. We had a couple of charge-offs in at the energy book that perhaps raised our charge-off level a little bit higher this quarter. But when you peel
componenttext: Thank you, Marty, that's a very insightful question on the bones of our portfolio and I think you nailed it. We had a couple of charge-offs in at the energy book that perhaps raised our charge-off level a little bit higher this quarter. But when you peel it back, you see energy charge-offs or you see our total charge-off levels, including energy, only at 39 basis points, still within what we expect to achieve of our full year guidance, even including these couple of items. And x-energy, as I said, we've got a charge-off level in at the whole rest of the book of only 19 basis points. So the rest of our book has a credit profile that frankly looks terrific. And as we work our way through the energy issues in the short term, I think you'll see the power of the rest of the portfolio coming through relatively quickly.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Marty, I think we're continuing to say we're pristine as it relates to the energy portfolio. We've been very diligent and very focused, and we've assembled a tight group focused on this portfolio because we really want to come out of this quarter say
componenttext: Yes, Marty, I think we're continuing to say we're pristine as it relates to the energy portfolio. We've been very diligent and very focused, and we've assembled a tight group focused on this portfolio because we really want to come out of this quarter saying that we've pressed hit, that we've got most of this behind us from a charge of standpoint as Aleem said, I think we're clearly more than halfway through. And then that will have a positive impact on the provision going forward. So we put a lot of shoulder to the wheel find this quarter to be able to say, we're [indiscernible].

componenttext: Thanks, Matt. I think the effect of the securities portfolio has sort of 2 effects. One is growth in the book at the lower coming on yield than the portfolio overall. So it's about 1 basis point or so. It maybe, as we look forward, it is already incorporated in our guidance. But think of it in the context of around 1 basis point a quarter.

componenttextpreview: A question for you guys, I guess first, maybe to follow up on some of the NIM questions, anything that you guys can do assuming that maybe rates stay lower for longer than we might have previously assumed, any additional strategies that you might pursue o
componenttext: A question for you guys, I guess first, maybe to follow up on some of the NIM questions, anything that you guys can do assuming that maybe rates stay lower for longer than we might have previously assumed, any additional strategies that you might pursue or implement moving forward to mitigate further compression here?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the things that we're doing and you're seeing is our portfolio mix and over time, what you're seeing is that we're growing our direct Consumer Lending portfolio at a very rapid base, as I said 26%. And that's helping our overall portfolio mix
componenttext: Well, one of the things that we're doing and you're seeing is our portfolio mix and over time, what you're seeing is that we're growing our direct Consumer Lending portfolio at a very rapid base, as I said 26%. And that's helping our overall portfolio mix and portfolio yields. And that is indeed helping to mitigate the effect of NIM overall. The other thing that we're doing is we're very actively managing the securities book and our swap stock and as we manage that over time, that will continue to, I think, help mitigate the effect of lower long-term rates on our book overall.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the portions that are dilutive to NIM, we're putting a lot of incentive pressure on relationship return. And the good news is we've got the capacity, we've built the capability to be very demanding of our teams to get a lot of fee income. And you
componenttext: And then the portions that are dilutive to NIM, we're putting a lot of incentive pressure on relationship return. And the good news is we've got the capacity, we've built the capability to be very demanding of our teams to get a lot of fee income. And you're seeing that manifest itself in that fee income level. So if we're putting on capital that's dilutive to NIM, we expect to get return that's accretive to noninterest income.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we said, we really try not to manage to a loan growth number so we look at production and then we look at paydowns and then we look at things that we may do to Aleem's point to continue to diversify the balance sheet and get us in a positive position.
componenttext: As we said, we really try not to manage to a loan growth number so we look at production and then we look at paydowns and then we look at things that we may do to Aleem's point to continue to diversify the balance sheet and get us in a positive position. Based on the things that we see now relative to all of those pluses and minuses that come in, I mean, 1% to 2% kind of range is probably not out of the realm of possibility. It's probably the right sort of loan but again, we don't manage to that kind of number. We really look at continuing to get positive production or we are continuing to expand what we're doing with the relationships and meeting all the hurdles. So we've got for a loan to come on the book double, it's got to get through a big in terms of overall hurdle rates.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016

componenttext: And Steve, to connect your questions, we have the great flexibility here at SunTrust to be able to be opportunistic. We've been able to buy portfolios where we see the ability to connect those clients with the rest of our offerings. And we have the ability to sell portfolios that we think are noncore or not going to be accretive to value over the long term. So we've got, as you said, decent organic growth. We've got hard-working teammates. But in addition to that, we've got great flexibility to be opportunistic to find ways to add value by both the buying and selling portfolios.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just ask a question about the credit cycle, sort of an overall question about it. You guys have made rather positive remarks here and as have a number of your regional and larger peers. Has there been a change in the outlook for the credit cycl
componenttext: If I could just ask a question about the credit cycle, sort of an overall question about it. You guys have made rather positive remarks here and as have a number of your regional and larger peers. Has there been a change in the outlook for the credit cycle right now? Because it looks like in the fourth and the first quarters, the commentary was a little bit more downbeat, and everybody seems to be looking at sort of the new improving credit cycle at this point. Is that a correct observation?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that we've got a sort of improving credit cycle here, Nancy, I think we're in the terrific part of the cycle overall. And you can see that in our numbers. 19 basis points of net charge-offs x-energy is spectacularly good. What we do think o
componenttext: I wouldn't say that we've got a sort of improving credit cycle here, Nancy, I think we're in the terrific part of the cycle overall. And you can see that in our numbers. 19 basis points of net charge-offs x-energy is spectacularly good. What we do think over the long term, over a cycle that with the credit profile that we've got, we should be expecting net charge-offs of between 40 and 70. That's what's built into our strategic plan and that's what we've talked about as well, what you should expect over the medium term. So we're in a very, very good part of the cycle. But to your point and I think this is where you're completely correct, this part has lasted a long time. We've been well under our 40 basis point expectation for many quarters and we continue to stay there. And when I take a look to the credit profile of the new loans that are coming on our books across all 3 segments, those credit profiles continue to be very, very strong. Consumer FICOs, consumer lending FICOs continue to come on at well north of a 750 and in many case, we are talking about 770, 780. And as you know, we're not a subprime lender. So the credit profile of what we're putting on continues to be very strong. I like what we're seeing in Wholesale Banking and what's coming on there. So it's lasting longer than we had perhaps thought it would a couple of years ago.

componenttext: Sort of I was going to answer that. It's really no change in intensity. As does change in time. And every quarter, it continues to be good, and will -- everyone will talk about the -- and that's a quarter more in this cycle.

componenttext: Yes, it's interesting because a lot of the parts of Florida continue to be really good. Are we -- we've not been a big player in the condo market in Miami all the way through and we continue not to be a big player. Multifamily there, we're sort of keeping an eye on. That would be a good example. The other markets in Florida from an industrial standpoint are much better. Job creation of Florida, remember Florida is one of the top job creating states in the the country. The port business in Florida is good. Yes, we see a lot of the East Coast, the East Coast to West Coast migration happening in the building that goes along with all the increased activity in Florida. So there are a couple of pockets. That would be a good example. And then maybe talk about sort of housing in general. We keep a close eye on housing in general overall in Florida. As you might imagine. We have probably the most heightened sensitivity of that of anybody. And we continue to be with really good developers. We continue to see pockets of opportunity. There's not a lot of crazy stuff going on, there's not a lot of land accumulation, there's not a lot of guys in the truck and all the things that we've got worried about, but our relative exposure is well-managed within that geography.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Coming back to your capital, you guys are obviously very well-capitalized. Aleem, you pointed to the success that you had during CCAR as being one of the lowest reductions in your CET1 ratio. I think you came in over 7%, with the bogey being 4.5%. You als
componenttext: Coming back to your capital, you guys are obviously very well-capitalized. Aleem, you pointed to the success that you had during CCAR as being one of the lowest reductions in your CET1 ratio. I think you came in over 7%, with the bogey being 4.5%. You also pointed out that acquisitions are really not what you're interested in doing at this time. So the question is, at your CET1 ratio of 9.7%, do you consider that to be too high? And if it is too high, would you -- toward the case that we expect in next year CCAR of not having the qualitative part of the test being applicable to banks of under $250 billion in assets, is that an opportunity for SunTrust to really give them that much more in a onetime special either dividend or buyback to bring those capital levels down to drive the profitability higher.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Gerard, I think our view is in the -- similar to the one you just is that at 9.7% that is more capital than we need to fundamentally run the operations of this company. And it is more capital than we need when you look at the very strong risk profil
componenttext: Well, Gerard, I think our view is in the -- similar to the one you just is that at 9.7% that is more capital than we need to fundamentally run the operations of this company. And it is more capital than we need when you look at the very strong risk profile across all of our books. What you have seen with us is that we have been looking for ways and finding ways to allow that ratio to drip down a little bit. The increase in dividend, the increase in buyback, what you should see with us over time is that that 9.7 should continue to drift down a little bit, a 1/10 here, 1/10 there and come down to something that over time, I wouldn't say -- I wouldn't expect a onetime massive repayment. But at that over time, we'd be able to bring it to something that is value added for all of our shareholders rather than retaining as much excess we have today.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there are couple of reasons. One is I think as an industry, we've even more demanding on and structure, so there's been a lot more equity in this part of the cycle. They are bigger players in this part of the cycle if I think particularly about th
componenttext: I think there are couple of reasons. One is I think as an industry, we've even more demanding on and structure, so there's been a lot more equity in this part of the cycle. They are bigger players in this part of the cycle if I think particularly about the single-family part. It's predominated now by bigger players, a lot more capital, a lot more staying power. There's been a lot of equity available, there are accepting, so allows them to have more equity in the to us. So I just think there's been a -- we can to have short memories and I think maybe and the case of commercial real estate our memory is a longer. This cycle than it has been in the past. But it's something in fast all of us, we're watching.
